Župani obmejnih občin na obisku pri Šarcu
04 Nov 2019, 18:03 by STA

Predsednik vlade Marjan Šarec je danes sprejel župane objemnih občin, ki so mu predstavili pobudo za zmanjšanje negativnih posledic nezakonitih migracij na življenje obmejnih prebivalcev. Dogovorili so se, da bodo oblikovali delovno skupino, ki bo pripravila sistemske rešitve za obvladovanje vplivov migracij in izboljšanje življenja ljudi ob meji.



Premier Marjan Šarec Foto: Leo Caharija

LJUBLJANA > Župani 16 občin ob meji s Hrvaško so skupno pobudo za zaščito prebivalcev in bivalnega okolja zaradi nezakonitih migracij na predsednika vlade naslovili konec septembra. Z njo so državo želeli spodbuditi, naj se loti urejanja težav v obmejnih občinah.
"Pravočasno moramo zagotoviti vse potrebno, da ne bi prišlo do dogodkov, v katerih bi bila lahko ogrožena človeška življenja ali da bi se nesprejemljivo poslabšali bivalni pogoji na obmejnih območjih," je razbrati iz pisma, ki so ga župani naslovili na vlado.
Na današnjem srečanju so župani Šarcu predstavili svoje predloge ukrepov, med katerimi so tudi dodatna sredstva za izgradnjo oziroma vzdrževanje cestne infrastrukture in čiščenje gozdov ter napotitev večjega števila policistov in vojakov na mejo.
"Pozdravljamo začetek dialoga in izmenjave pogledov. V marsičem se strinjamo, marsikje pa imamo različne poglede," je na novinarski konferenci po srečanju s premierjem ocenil župan občine Črnomelj Andrej Kavšek. Uspeli pa so se dogovoriti o oblikovanju delovne skupine predstavnikov občin in vlade, ki bo iskala sistemske rešitve za izboljšanje življenja obmejnih prebivalcev. Koordinator skupine bo minister za notranje zadeve Boštjan Poklukar, z delom pa naj bi začela v 14 dneh.
Danes tako župani od vlade niso dobili nobenih konkretnih obljub, saj so predvsem evidentirali težave, s katerimi se srečujejo, je pojasnil župan Ilirske Bistrice Emil Rojc. "Iščemo osnovno razumevanje države, da pri tem pomaga," pa je dodal župan občine Kostel Ivan Črnkovič.
Obmejne občine se po besedah županov srečujejo z različnimi težavami. V občini Kostel je na primer 19 vasi, ki nimajo javne razsvetljave, s pomanjkanjem ustrezne opreme za različne intervencije se srečujejo tudi gasilci.
Zato med drugim zahtevajo dodatna sredstva za postavitev svetilk javne razsvetljave, kar bo prispevalo k dvigu občutka varnosti prebivalcev ob meji, in za usposabljanje gasilcev za reševanje iz vode in na vodi.
Prav tako so predlagali, da država na prizadetih območjih zagotovi ustrezno višino nadomestila gospodarskim subjektom zaradi izpada prihodkov. Nekontrolirani migrantski tokovi namreč povzročajo med ljudmi strah in negotovost, kar se odraža v upadu obsega dejavnosti, posebej prizadeti so v gostinstvu in turizmu, so navedli.

Mayors of border communities visiting Sarac
04 Nov 2019, 17:03 by STA

Prime Minister Marjan Sarec today received the mayors of embracing municipalities who presented him with an initiative to reduce the negative effects of illegal migration on the lives of border residents. They agreed to set up a working group to come up with systemic solutions to manage the impact of migration and improve the lives of people along the border.



Prime Minister Marjan Sarec Photo: Leo Cahari

LJUBLJANA> The mayors of 16 municipalities along the border with Croatia have addressed the Prime Minister at the end of September with a joint initiative to protect residents and the environment due to illegal migration. It wanted to encourage the country to tackle the problems in the border municipalities.
"We need to provide everything in time to prevent incidents that could endanger human lives or to unacceptably worsen living conditions in border areas," a letter sent by mayors to the government read.
At today's meeting, the mayors of Sarac presented their proposals for measures, including additional funds for the construction or maintenance of road infrastructure and forest clearing, as well as the deployment of more police officers and soldiers to the border.
"We welcome the start of dialogue and the exchange of views. We agree in many respects, but in many respects we have different views," Mayor of Črnomelj Andrej Kavšek said at a news conference after meeting with the Prime Minister. However, they managed to agree on the creation of a working group of representatives of municipalities and the government, which will look for systemic solutions for improving the lives of border residents. The group will be co-ordinated by the Minister of the Interior, Boštjan Poklukar, and is expected to start working within 14 days.
Today, such mayors did not receive any concrete promises from the government, as they primarily recorded the problems they were facing, explained Ilirska Bistrica Mayor Emil Rojc. "We are looking for a basic understanding of the country to help with this," added Kostel Mayor Ivan Crnkovic.
According to the mayors, border municipalities are facing various problems. In the municipality of Kostel, for example, there are 19 villages that do not have public lighting, and firefighters are also facing the lack of adequate equipment for various interventions.
Therefore, they require, among other things, additional funding for the installation of public lighting lamps, which will help to raise residents' sense of security along the border, and to train firefighters for water and water rescue.
They also suggested that the state in the affected areas provide an adequate level of compensation to economic operators for the loss of revenue. Uncontrolled migrant flows are causing fear and insecurity among people, which is reflected in the decline in the volume of activities, especially in the catering and tourism sectors, they said.
